Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186,.proposition: This is a civil action brought by Plaintiff Emily Carter ("Plaintiff") against her landlord, Defendant Robert Thompson ("Defendant"), for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, § 14.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223,.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223, § 2, because this action arises out of events occurring in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the property at issue is located within this judicial district.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from "substantial interference" with their tenancy. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); *Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 849 (1997).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” in Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and describes it as protection against serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises. In discussing the common-law covenant that § 14 builds on, the court emphasizes interference with the tenant’s rights, not mere technical breaches, which aligns with the modern formulation of protection against “substantial interference.” Although the exact phrase “substantial interference” is not used, the court’s description and citations (e.g., Winchester v. O’Brien, Blackett v. Olanoff) support that standard.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 849.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from "substantial interference" with their tenancy. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); *Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 849 (1997).
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 849.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about whether a lead paint statutory violation alone constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it focuses on the landlord’s fault standard (at least negligence). It does not explicitly restate the “substantial interference” formulation, but it relies on and applies prior quiet-enjoyment cases (including Simon) that define breaches in terms of significant interference with tenancy. Thus, while indirect, the case is consistent with and supportive of the substantial-interference conception of the covenant, though it is not the clearest source for that specific phrasing.
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 849.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises…. Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”}

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Noise may constitute a substantial interference sufficient to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); *Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 953 (1978).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that serious interferences with use of the premises—such as loss of use of sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreational areas—can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of criminal drug activity and lack of security measures, not noise per se. The court does not discuss noise alone as a basis for substantial interference, nor does it hold that noise by itself constitutes a substantial interference in violation of the covenant. Thus this case does not directly support the specific proposition that noise, as such, may constitute a substantial interference sufficient to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. A.raw_text: *Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 953 (1978)
*Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. A.proposition: Noise may constitute a substantial interference sufficient to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); *Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. App. Ct. 953 (1978).
*Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal appellate decision dealing with joinder/severance, a motion to suppress (search warrant and entry), and admissibility of photographs. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or noise as an interference with tenancy. Because the opinion neither discusses quiet enjoyment nor noise as a substantial interference, it cannot support the cited proposition for that legal principle.
*Bosse v. City of Gloucester*, 6 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant passage: the opinion concerns criminal procedure issues (severance, search warrant validity, and evidentiary rulings) and does not address covenants of quiet enjoyment, noise, or landlord‑tenant interference.]

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant's conduct was deliberate or at least grossly negligent, as evidenced by his repeated refusal to take meaningful action in response to Plaintiff's numerous complaints. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 717–18 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion does not frame the landlords’ liability in terms of deliberate or grossly negligent conduct, nor does it emphasize a repeated refusal to act. Instead, the court expressly says the landlords did not intend to create the conditions, notes they made some attempts to remedy the problem, and grounds liability in the natural and probable consequences of what they did, failed to do, or permitted, regardless of intent. The case therefore supports an objective, control-based standard for breach of quiet enjoyment, not a requirement of deliberate or grossly negligent inaction.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: "The judge further found that, although the landlords did not intend to create the conditions, the landlords ‘had it within their control to correct the conditions which... amounted to a constructive eviction of each [tenant].’ He also found that the landlords promised each tenant to correct the situation, that the landlords made some attempt to remedy the problem, but they were unsuccessful... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling."

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover actual damages resulting from Defendant's breach, including but not limited to damages for emotional distress and financial harm. See *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.support_reasoning: The case is a landlord-tenant/ch. 93A decision and does recognize recovery of emotional distress and economic loss as compensable "actual damages" under G.L. c. 93A, but it does not involve, or discuss, a traditional contract "breach" or general contract damages doctrine. The emotional distress and diminution in value damages are tied specifically to statutory consumer protection and warranty-of-habitability claims, not to a generic rule that a plaintiff in any breach case may recover actual damages including emotional distress and financial harm. Thus it does not squarely support the broad proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.relevant_excerpt: "On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.... We conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A."

*Armstrong v. Gabriel*, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Plaintiff is also entitled to the statutory remedy of rent abatement due to Defendant's failure to uphold the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Armstrong v. Gabriel*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 533, 537–38 (1983).
*Armstrong v. Gabriel*, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving a rape conviction and issues like prosecutorial argument, jury instructions, evidentiary rulings, voir dire, ineffective assistance, and polling the jury. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or statutory rent abatement. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition about a tenant’s entitlement to rent abatement for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Armstrong v. Gabriel*, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from his rape conviction in the Superior Court. He raises a number of issues on appeal. He seeks reversal on the ground that improper statements by the prosecutor in her closing argument denied him a fair trial. He also claims that reversible error occurred in the jury instructions on reasonable doubt and consciousness of guilt, the exclusion of certain evidence, the judge’s refusal to ask certain questions of the venire on voir dire, the failure to provide effective assistance of counsel, and the judge’s refusal to poll the jury after the verdict. We affirm the conviction.
